column1: Södertälje ( SU(R)D-ər-TEL-yə; Swedish: [sœdɛˈʈɛ̂lːjɛ] (listen)) is a city in Södermanland and Stockholm County
column2: Sweden and seat of Södertälje municipality. As of 2017
column3: it has 72 704 inhabitants. Södertälje is located at Mälarens confluence in to the Baltic Sea through the lock in the Södertälje Canal. Since year 2000
column4: it is the largest city located entirely within the province of Södermanland.

column2: about 4000 years BC it is estimated that the first people reached the area around what is today Södertälje. They formed settlements around 3
column4: when the peasant culture is believed to have reached the area. Around 1500 - 400 BC
column5: the strait between Lake Mälaren and the Baltic Sea narrowed due to the post-glacial rebound. That boats henceforth had to be towed over the sand ridge created job opportunities. Trade and service emerged.Ansgar passed through Södertälje on his voyages to Birka in his efforts to make Sweden Christian in 829. The first time Södertälje is mentioned in historical sources was in 1070 when Adam of Bremen mentions the town in a description of the road between Skara and Birka in his work Gesta Hammaburgensis Ecclesiae pontificum. The area had however been inhabited long before then. Södertälje received city privileges in the 1300s.The castle Telge Hus was built at Slottsholmen during the 1300s. From here
column6: Telgehus county was administered between the years 1318 and 1527. The county included Öknebo
column7: Hölebo and parts of Svartlösa districts. Archaeological excavations have shown that the castle was surrounded by a moat. It is still partially visible on Slottsholmen's north-western shore.Originally
column8: the city was simply called Tälje (several spellings are known; including Telge
column11: the prefix “Söder” (English: South) was added to distinguish from the then recently founded town of Norrtälje
column12: located 110 km northeast of the city. Statistics Sweden started using the modern spelling in 1900.The city first used St. Olof in its coat of arms. In the beginning of the 17th century he was replaced by Ragnhild of Tälje (Swedish: Sankta Ragnhild). After her pilgrimages to Rome and Jerusalem
column13: her relics are said to have been buried in Södertälje.Duke Charles (subsequently became King Charles) actively invested in Södertälje as a commercial and maritime city during his time as Duke of Södermanland
column14: which contributed to growth. A port was built just south of the city. It was not until the 1740s that the city began with industrial manufacturing in addition to shipping and trade.

column2: but during the 19th century it became necessary to extend it to be able to receive larger vessels. In 1819 the Södertälje Canal was inaugurated after 13 years of construction. Just over forty years later
column4: rail traffic between Södertälje and Stockholm commenced. The Western Main Line for trains between the east and west coast of Sweden opened in 1862
column5: with a station in the city.Around this time Södertälje became known as a seaside resort for Stockholmers. In 1849 the Södertälje Bathing Facilities in Badparken park was opened
column6: with both a cold bath facility and a hot bath house. The bathhouses and the Societetshus venue have been demolished
column7: but the Bath hotel at Järnagatan street
column8: Strandhotellet hotel
column9: Stadsparken park and Villa Bellevue still remain from the resort era
column10: which lasted for almost a hundred years until 1945.The tradition of selling the local pretzels Södertäljekringlor is several hundred years old. They had their absolute heyday during the resort era
column11: i.e. around the beginning of the 19th century onwards. They were typically sold by older women
column12: often referred to as Kringelgummumor (English: Pretzel ladies). Sale of pretzels was predominantly done to tourists
column13: and especially at the city’s railway stations. The sale of pretzels
column14: among other aspects of the resort town
column15: was described in the magazine Svenska Familj-Journalen (English: Swedish Family Journal) in 1881.By the 1900s
column16: Södertälje's population had grown to over 8
column17: 000 people. Around the turn of the century several large factories were established in the city: Svenska Centrifug AB (1896)
column21: Tobaksmonopolet (1915) och Wedaverken (1917). Perhaps most interesting is the formation of VABIS
column22: Vagnfabriks-Aktiebolaget in Södertelge (1891). In 1911 it merged with Scania and formed Scania-Vabis. Nowadays
column24: the company only uses the name Scania AB.

column10: Södertälje was still a fairly small town with a largely homogeneous population of 33
column13: the demographics of the city changed radically. The industrial boom and the structural transformation led to economic development and increased investments in the city’s industries. The large companies Scania-Vabis and Astra were in high demand of labour. Recruitment was primarily made from parts of the country that were severely affected by the industrial boom
column14: mainly Norrland. When the manpower from other parts of the country was insufficient
column15: foreign labour was brought in. Most of the migrant workers came from Finland
column19: while many Assyrians / Syriacs settled in Södertälje. At the end of the 1990s
column21: and now constitute the largest immigrant group. In total
column22: about 39 percent of the city’s population are first or second generation immigrants. In 2013
column23: there were reports in the media that a parallel society founded by the Assyrian and Syrian minorities had emerged
column25: rules and a banking systems without control from society. Swedish law enforcement allocated extensive resources. A trial against the mafia like organisation Södertäljenätverket (English: The Södertälje network) ended in 2013.Construction of Almnäs garrison started in 1970. Svea Engineer Corps and the Engineering Troops Cadet School (INGKAS) relocated to Almnäs. They were joined by Swedint
column26: the Armed Forces International training school
column28: the Life Guards were also present at Almnäs. After 1996
column29: the armed forces underwent a major reorganisation
column30: and left Almnäs altogether in 2004. The area is now a business park.

column1: Many of the city’s modern attractions were built in the 1980s. A museum based on the book La Science Amusante by French writer Arthur Good was built. The museum is called Tom Tits Experiment after the author’s pen name Tom Tit. The new bath house Sydpoolen opened in 1987
column2: and is now one of the most visited bathing facilities in the country. During the 2010 and 2020 centuries
column3: several infrastructure projects were completed or started. Further widening of the canal and the lock was initiated
column4: as well as the upgrade of the railway around Södertälje Hamn railway station to increase capacity.

column1: The City of Södertälje was transformed to a city municipality during the Swedish municipal reforms of 1862. The city grew and subsequently incorporated Västertälje parish in 1946 and Östertälje parish in 1963. The city municipality expanded further in 1967
column2: until it became the seat of the present-day Södertälje Municipality.Within the Church of Sweden
column3: Södertälje was part of Södertälje City parish. It incorporated the western part of Södertälje landsförsamling in 1946
column4: and received the name Södertälje församling (English: Södertälje parish). It has since also incorporated the parish of Tveta. Between 1973 and 2010
column5: part of the city was part of Västertälje parish. The eastern part of Södertälje still belongs to Östertälje parish.

column2: the city belonged to the judicial district Södertälje Council Court. In 1971
column3: it was changed to Södertälje District Court.

column2: the city was hit by two major fires; in 1630 and 1650. After the fire in 1650
column3: the devastation was vast. All important buildings except the church were destroyed; including the school and town hall. After the fires
column4: extensive urban planning was implemented under the leadership of Anders Torstensson
column5: where the old irregular medieval neighbourhoods were replaced by a grid plan of streets. The 1650s plan remained largely in place until the redevelopment of the city centre in the 1960s
column6: and still characterises many parts of the central areas. Most of the older buildings have disappeared due to city fires or demolition.

column1: The central parts of Södertälje are today mainly the neighbourhood around what is commonly referred to as called Gågatan
column2: which is the pedestrian part of Storgatan street. Stortorget was originally the absolute centre of the city. The reason that the area would subsequently expand (mainly in a southerly direction) is largely due to the fact that the Central Railway Station was placed near the city park. Unlike most other cities in the country
column3: no railroad has ever been drawn through Södertälje's central parts
column4: which meant that very little central area had to be designated for tracks. Another interesting detail is that the old Södertälje largely consisted of wooden houses. It’s commonly believed that this is because Södertälje never has been a major administrative centre
column5: such as a county capital or episcopal see. For a trade city
column6: it wooden structures were considered sufficient. The original wooden buildings are especially well preserved in the areas around Fredsgatan and Västgötagatan streets. The older wooden houses that previously existed in the central parts have largely been moved up to Torekällberget
column7: which is Södertälje's open-air city museum. The first apartment building in stone was built as late as 1865. The property was at Järnagatan 8
column8: next to Saltsjötorget square
column9: and was built by industrialist DJ Ekeberg. When Järnagatan was lowered in 1907
column10: the basement level became the areas that are occupied by shops today.

column1: Södertälje’s old City Hotel is situated on Saltsjötorget square. It was built to accommodate the high demand for rooms that arose during the time the city was a seaside resort. The City council decided to commission a new hotel on the site. Architect Ernst Haegglund was hired to design the building. The square also houses the old building for Svensk-Engelska Mineralolje AB
column2: which was completed between 1931 and 1932 after drawings by architect Albin Stark. Between 1991 and 2008
column3: the building served as city hall. The current city hall was built on the opposite side of the central station. The new building was designed by BSK Arkitekter
column4: and inaugurated in the autumn of 2008 by King Carl XVI Gustaf. The building serves both as municipal offices and cultural centre.

column1: The Central Railway Station is situated behind the City Hotel. It is one of few Swedish railway stations with two station houses. The first building is entirely in brick
column2: and was designed in 1860 by Adolf W. Edelsvärd. The yellow station building was added in the 1910s and was designed by Folke Zettervall. Today
column3: only the yellow building is used for ticket sales. The older station house is occupied by a bar
column4: café and convenience store. The open square between the two station houses
column5: the bus station and the railway tracks is called Stationsplan.

column1: To the west of the station
column2: across Järnagatan lies Villa Bellevue. During the era when Södertälje was a seaside resort
column3: it was one of the city's most notable buildings. It was built in 1871 by the royal pastry chef Davidsson
column4: after drawings by architect Ernst Jacobsson. The new city hall is situated next-door to the property. Villa Bellevue is located on the border between the city centre and the centrally located neighbourhood of Mariekälla
column5: which is named after one of the city's water springs. On Parkgatan
column6: which is a parallel street to the district's main street Mariekällgatan
column7: lies Villa Walhall. The villa was built in 1875 by engineer Ludvig Jerving. Villa Walhall and Villa Bellevue were considered so typical of the resort town Södertälje that they were described and depicted in a series of articles in the magazine Svenska Familj-Journalen in 1881.Most restaurants and bars are located around Lake Maren. Marenplan square (formerly called Stadshamnen port)
column8: served as Södertälje's most important port until the construction of Mälarhamnen port in 1880. When Marenplan served as city port
column9: ships carrying goods would moor there
column10: and sell their merchandise to individuals and traders waiting at the quay. Boat traffic to inner Maren continued until 1963
column11: when the Maren Bridge between Strandgatan and Lotsudden was built. The bridge was only intended as a temporary solution
column12: and became demolished in 1993. The Maren Bridge subsequently replaced a pedestrian and bicycle bridge. The initial plan was to have the bridge removed during the summer months to allow boats to moor in inner Maren seasonally. The bridge subsequently became year-round fixed link. The Sorbonne house lies where Lotsudden and Marenplan meet. It was built in 1905
column13: and served as studio for photographer David Sorbon until 1928. The building was completely renovated in 1985-86
column14: to accommodate several residential apartments and a restaurant.

column1: Just above Marenplan lies the square Olof Palmes plats
column2: which got its name after the murdered Prime Minister Olof Palme. Among the buildings on the square is the old bank palace that used to belong to Södertälje Sparbank. Like many other buildings in Södertälje
column3: the city's patron saint Ragnhild of Tälje (Swedish: Sankta Ragnhild) id depicted on the facade. The importance of Olof Palmes plats was especially high when it served as hub for the city buses
column4: which have since been moved to the Central Railway Station. The streets Storgatan
column5: Badhusgatan and Järnagatan begin at Olof Palmes plats.

column1: Most department stores and high street shopping are located on Gågatan (English: the Pedestrian street)
column2: which is the pedestrian part of Storgatan that runs between Torekällgatan and Stortorget. The pedestrian street is dominated by modern department stores
column3: built during the 1960s. The largest are Kringlan (architect Erik and Tore Ahlsén)
column4: Luna
column5: Åhléns and Telgehuset (which initially was a Domus department store). A notable exception to the otherwise modern structures is Skandinaviska Enskilda Bankens bank palace
column6: which was built between 1901 and 1902 at the initiative of the tobacco trader TH. Gustafsson.  The local architect Tore E: son Lindhberg made the drawings. In 1939 the facade was modernized
column7: and subsequently restored when the building was completely renovated in 1975.

column1: The hospital on Orionkullen was built 1777-78. Until 1823
column2: the building served as lazaretto of the Royal Order of the Seraphim. After 1823
column3: the building became a private residence. From 1844
column4: the buildings were used as city hall and for higher education. In 1907 the council administration moved from Orionkullen
column5: allowing the educational institution to expand. As the school faculty moved to the new secondary school building at Erik Dahlberg’s road
column6: a girl’s school moved in. The girl’s school at Orionkullen closed in 1968. The building is home to a cultural centre today.

column1: The area where the secondary school moved is east of the canal
column2: the Museum of Biology and the present day city hospital. After the 1960s upper secondary school reform
column3: the institution became a Gymnasium Secondary school. Close to the school lies Mälarparken
column4: which is home to the professional Miniature golf course. They local team has won several championships. The City Council offices were also located by the park before moving to the intersection of Nygatan/Torekällgatan. Södertälje's current hospital is across the street from the secondary school. It is houses one of the county's six trauma centres. It opened in 1907
column5: but has been expanded and renovated on several occasions
column6: most recently in 2017.

column1: As the land post-glacial rebound made Södertälje Canal shallower
column2: it became increasingly difficult for merchants to get between Lake Mälaren and the Baltic Sea to sell their goods. It was decided to build a square in Södertälje
column3: where they could meet to and hold markets. The location of the square was carefully selected so it would be located equidistant between the city’s ports at Baltic Sea and Lake Mälaren. This way
column4: merchants did not have to drag their goods longer than was absolutely necessary. The main square in Södertälje is thus not primarily designed as a trading place for the city’s inhabitants themselves. For hundreds of years
column5: Stortorget was very important because of the lively square trade held there. At that time
column6: Stortorget was regarded as the city's centremost place. In modern times
column7: when most trade is conducted in stores
column8: the importance of the square has diminished. Marenplan has increasingly taken over the role as the most central location in the city. The most famous building on Stortorget is perhaps the old yellow wooden City Hall building
column9: which was opened in 1735. The City Hall originally stood on the west side of the square. It was temporarily relocated to Västra Kanalgatan during the redevelopment of the city centre in the 1960s. Since 1982
column10: the City Hall has been in its present location. Today it houses art galleries and a café. Across the square lies the current Södertälje District Court
column11: which was designed by Åke Lindqvist

column1: On the northern side of Stortorget square is Sankta Ragnhilds Kyrka (English: Church of Ragnhild of Tälje) from the 1100s–1300s. It is the main church in Södertälje parish in the Diocese of Strängnäs. After many renovations
column2: the church is today a large building with three arches. The oldest parts consist of grey brick walls that comprise the lower parts of the bell tower and the two westernmost compartments of the longhouse. Renovations were made after the city fire in 1650. Further additions were made in the 1670s
column3: when the Cronberg-Hackerska choir in the middle of the southern wall. It was probably designed by Erik Dahlbergh
column4: and is now used as a baptismal chapel. During the fires during the Russian Pillage of 1719–21
column5: it was one of few buildings that survived. A major restoration under the direction of architect B. Romare took place between 1960 and 1961. A few years after this
column6: two of the windows next to the baptismal chapel received new stained glass windows by F. Heybrock. The exterior of the church was repaired in 1986 - 87
column7: with the facades partially receiving their current colour scheme.

column1: Above Stortorget and Gågatan lies Nygatan street
column2: which is almost exclusively home to modern buildings. Among them
column3: Roxyhuset (English: the Roxy house) is worth mentioning. The building was designed by architect Björn Hedvall
column4: and was completed in 1939. Its lower level housed a cinema until 1992
column5: when it moved to Lunagallerian on Storgatan street. After this
column6: the Roxy House was partially renovated
column7: and a convenience store
column8: restaurant and nightclub moved in. Nygatan street is also home to Södertälje’s old Telegraph station. It was built 1939-1940
column9: after drawings by U. Ahlbom. Around the time the telegraph station was put into operation
column10: automation of the Swedish telephone network began. The station was subsequently closed after just 30 years. Below the station lies Torekällskolan school. It is the oldest of the city's schools that is still in use. Since its opening in 1869
column11: it has been rebuilt on numerous occasions.

column1: Holmfastvägen road begins in the city's central parts
column2: and connects to the area Geneta in the western parts of the city. The road originally went all the way to Näsby
column3: next to Lake Måsnaren. It was built during the 11th century
column4: thus marking the early importance of the area around Södertälje. A large runic inscription called the Holmfast Inscriptions (Swedish: Holmfastristningen) describe the construction by Viking Holmfast
column5: including reinforcing the land and building bridges. Archaeologists find it likely that Holmfast's old bridges remain under the roadway. Around the engraving
column6: which is located in close proximity to the road
column7: have today been cleaned up and put up signs from the Swedish National Heritage Board with translations of the inscription.Retail parks are a fairly new feature in Södertälje. Until the early 2000s
column8: the only really large collection of shops
column10: was Weda in the eastern part of the city. With the construction of Moraberg köpcentrum
column12: availability of shops increased. The area around Scaniarinken previously contained some shops
column13: but has subsequently been extended to form Vasa handelsplats. Some shops are also located around Hansaplan in the area Södra
column14: close to Södertälje Hamn railway station.

column2: when the upgraded canal opened
column3: there was just one single bridge connecting the eastern and western parts of the city. It was a swing bridge
column4: near the old lock
column5: at Mälarehamnen. It was built in 1910 at Södertelge Verkstäder. After it was replaced by a more modern bridge
column6: the old swing bridge was moved to Stäksundet in the province of Uppland.

column1: At times there was also an iron bridge that was rolled out over the lock itself. It was also possible to use rowing boats to cross. Boat services were usually operated women
column2: predominantly dalkullor. A crossing would cost 2-5 öre
column3: depending on season. The rowing boats could carry up to around five people. At the narrowest place
column4: the distance across was just 12 metres. Embarking by Viksgatan street was especially popular. Many were willing to pay to avoid having to walk to the swing bridge and back again if they lived around the areas of Tältet or Hagaberg. During the winter
column5: simple footbridges supported by pontoons were laid out – making the crossing free of charge.

column1: There are currently tree places where it’s possible to cross the canal on foot or by car
column2: plus two railway bridges. The northernmost link is the Mälarbron bridge
column3: which has three predecessors: the swing bridge from the 19th century
column4: and another swing bridge that was used between 1910 and 1924. Both stood about 150 meters south of the current Mälarbron bridge. In 1924
column5: the first bascule bridge opened. It was often referred to as simply "Klaffbron" or ”Landsvägsbron” (English: “the Bascule bridge” or "the Country Road Bridge"). It was a double flap bridge with two fixed bridge vaults on each side. Ragnar Hjort made the architectural design. After World War II
column6: it could no longer handle the increased traffic volume. Hence
column7: the current Mälarbron was commissioned
column8: and opened in 1971. It is equipped with a control tower. Today the bridge together with the whole route from Landsort in to Mälaren is remote controlled from the locks in Södertälje.

column1: The most central crossing is at the canal lock
column2: and consists of the two bridges Marenbron
column3: which crosses Lake Maren
column4: and Slussbron
column5: which crosses the canal itself. In 1963 the first bridge over the Maren was built. It was intended as a temporary link
column6: and was subsequently demolished in 1993. The Marenbron was later replaced by a pedestrian and bicycle bridge. The initial plan was to have it removed during the summer
column7: allowing small boats to reach the inner parts of the lake. It did however become a year-round fixed link. In September 2003
column8: a referendum among the residents of Södertälje Municipality was held
column9: where they could decide if they wanted a new car bridge to be commissioned at the site. The costs were estimated to 40 million Swedish krona. At the referendum
column10: 56.5 percent voted no and 39.4 percent favourably
column11: meaning no new car bridge was built. Suggestions to build an arch bridge or bascule bridge for pedestrians and cyclists have been brought forward. It would allow boats to pass under and reach the inner parts of Lake Maren in the centremost parts of the city. Pedestrians have also been able to cross the canal itself by walking across the lock gates.

column1: The Saltsjöbron and E4-bron bridges constitute the southernmost crossing for cars and pedestrians. They run between the districts of Södra and Viksängen in Södertälje's southern parts. Saltsjöbron is a bascule bridge
column2: and the road that goes across it is called Viksängsleden. It is equipped with a bicycle and pedestrian path. E4-bron is a vertical-lift bridge
column3: crossed by the eponymous E4 Motorway
column4: and marks the southern fork with E20. It was built in the 1960s
column5: together with the motorways around the city. Saltsjöbron was built in 2002 to relieve the E4-bron
column6: and to provide an alternative in case of mechanical failure after one occurred in 1990.

column1: Parallel to Saltsjöbron and E4-bron lays the railway bridge predominantly used by local and freight trains. It opened in the summer of 2010
column2: and is hence the youngest bridge in the city. It replaced the old railway bridge from 1921
column3: which was located immediately east of the current bridge. The old bridge was replaces as it was unable to handle heavy trains
column4: nor deep-going maritime vessels. It was also too noisy. The distance between the bridge pillars on the new bridge is wider
column5: to enable the canal to be broadened further. The old railway bridge had a small pedestrian path. After it was demolished in autumn of 2010
column6: pedestrians must cross at Saltsjöbron instead. The old railway bridge replaced an even older bridge from 1860 that crossed around the area of Tältet. That bridge was demolished in the 1920s
column7: when Saltskog railway station had been closed and replaced Södertälje Södra railway station (subsequently renamed Södertälje Hamn).

column1: The Igelsta Bridge is the southernmost of the city's bridges. It is the main route for long distance and regional trains across Södertälje Canal. It is 2140 meters long
column2: reaches as high as 48 meters above the canal
column3: making it Sweden's tallest and longest railway bridge (after the Swedish part of the Øresund Bridge). Igelstabron spans between Pershagen and Hall. The bridge forms part of the Grödingebanan on the Western Main Line and opened in 1995. Södertälje Syd railway station is located on the bridge’s eastern abutment.

column1: Södertälje belongs to the Diocese of Strängnäs within the Church of Sweden. A total of eight church buildings are located within Södertälje. The oldest and most important to this day is Sankta Ragnhilds kyrka (English: Church of Ragnhild of Tälje) from the 1100s–1300s
column2: which is located on the main square Stortorget. Further churches belonging to Södertälje parish are Sankt Mikaels kyrka in Geneta
column3: Hovsjö kyrka and Lina kyrka in Lina Hage. Lina kyrka was designed by Tallius Myhrman. It is renowned for its design
column4: and has been depicted in several Swedish architecture magazines.

column1: The main church in Östertälje parish is Alla Helgons kyrka in Östertälje . The parish also operates Hagabergs kapell chapel on the grounds of Hagaberg Folk high school. It was built in 1894 as a chapel on Vartofta farm in Västergötland. The chapel was moved to its present location in 1914
column2: after having been dismantled and transported by train. In the centre of the Brunnsäng area lays the church Brunnsäng kyrka
column3: which is the youngest in the city. There is also a chapel at Södertälje hospital.There are several congregations not affiliated with the Church of Sweden in the city. The Catholic Church in Sweden has Sankt Ansgar’s church by Mälarbron. The associated parish has members from a vast hinterland around the city. There is a sizable community of Christian orthodox in Södertälje. The Syriac Orthodox Church has two bishops in the city
column4: besides to five Syrian Orthodox churches
column5: two soccer teams and a TV channel that airs programs in Neo-Aramaic
column6: Arabic and English. The minority group of Sweden Finns have services in Finnish language within the Church of Sweden. There is also a Finnish speaking Pentecostal congregation.

column1: The E4 and E20 Motorways have their southern fork after which they form separate roads at Saltskog junction in Södertälje. Other major roads passing through the city are Riksväg 1 (to Trosa and further south)
column2: and Länsväg 225 (to Nynäshamn via Ösmo). These towns
column3: plus Mariefred
column4: Stockholm
column5: Trosa and Gnesta
column6: are served by regular buses. Riksväg 57 (to Katrineholm via Flen ) also begins in Södertälje.

column1: Given the many railways that go to or through Södertälje
column2: services are both frequent and diverse. International trains to cities like Oslo and Copenhagen call in Södertälje
column3: in addition to local
column4: regional and national services. There are four stations within the urban area of the city: Södertälje Centrum (central station)
column5: Södertälje Syd
column6: Södertälje Hamn and Östertälje.Due to its topography and the fact that it is divided by a canal
column7: it has been difficult to build good train connections in and through the city.  Despite this
column8: Södertälje is one of the largest railway hubs in Sweden. When the railway to Södertälje was commissioned
column9: it was decided that the main line would not be drawn through what was then the immediate city centre. The decision was one of the factors behind the urban planning of the area Mariekälla
column10: just south of the Järnatullen city toll.The railway station in Södertälje became Södertelge Öfre (English: Södertälje Upper). Its initial name of "Södertelge" caused confusion as it was then well outside the city
column11: which was resolved by the name change. The central station was named Södertelge nedre (English: Södertälje lower). In 1885
column12: the stations' names were changed again
column13: with Södertelge upper being named Saltskog
column14: and Södertelge nedre becoming Södertälje Central. Both railway stations opened in October 1860
column15: together with the railway to Stockholm. The railway would subsequently become extended further south towards Katrineholm and Gothenburg and become the Western Main Line. The railway Norra Södermanlands Järnväg through the northern part of the province of Södermanland opened in 1895
column16: which meant that Södertälje also got a railway connection to Eskilstuna. Södertelge Öfre opened with a simple wooden station building with two platforms and a warehouse. A modern stone building replaced the old station in 1885.

column1: The Central Railway Station stands out by having two station buildings. The oldest is entirely in red brick
column2: and was designed by the railway architect Adolf W. Edelsvärd. The yellow building was added in the 1910s and was designed by Folke Zettervall . In October 1921
column3: the station Södertälje Södra opened together with the new double track through the city. Södertälje Södra replaced the old railway station in Saltskog
column4: whose station house was demolished in 1947 or possibly earlier.

column1: The next traffic diversion occurred in 1994
column2: when the Igelsta Bridge opened. Unlike the other bridges in Södertälje
column3: it is built on sail-free altitude above the canal. Södertälje Syd railway station (English: Södertälje South) is located on its western abutment. It is the city’s current station serviced by long distance inter-city and high-speed rail. The old railroad below the bridge is used by commuter trains. Platforms are located both on the bridge
column4: and on the old tracks below. The waiting hall is situated on a concourse level between the tracks. After Södertälje Syd opened
column5: the stations in the city once again changed their names. Södertälje Södra became Södertälje Hamn (English: port)
column6: and the Central Station became Södertälje Centrum. Igelsta station had previously changed name to Östertälje.Today
column7: Södertälje is a railway hub for Svealandsbanan
column8: the Western Main Line and Nyköpingsbanan . Both the more recent Grödingebanan for long distance trains and the old main line run in the direction towards Stockholm. The many railways that pass through Södertälje mean that it’s possible to travel to Sweden's three major cities Stockholm
column9: Gothenburg and Malmö without changing train.

column1: The first functioning canal through Södertälje was built between 1806 and 1819 after drawings by water engineering engineer Eric Nordewall. The canal has since been extended and broadened on several occasions. Within the scope of the Mälarprojektet initiative
column2: the canal was expanded between 2016-2020 to handle vessels that are 160 meters long and 23 meters wide. The project encompassed a longer and wider lock
column3: and dredging of the sides of the canal to make them straighter. The width of the water surface was thus kept unchanged.Every day
column4: over 40 boats pass through Södertälje canal
column5: carrying more than 5 million metric tonnes of goods each year. Of these
column6: about 4 million tonnes are shipped into Lake Mälaren
column7: and 1 million tonnes to the Baltic Sea. Primarily
column8: coal
column11: limestone and chalk are carried through the canal. The port of Södertälje also acts as a transhipment terminal from rail to trucks and ships.The port of Södertälje consists of four wharfs: Sydhamnen
column14: and Uthamnen. Sydhamnen primarily handles containers and roll-on/roll-off cargo
column15: including imported cars. The oldest wharf is Uthamnen. Here
column16: smaller quantities of odd bulk cargo are handled
column17: mainly road salt. Combustible goods are primarily transported to the Igelstahamnen to the Igelsta heating plant. Oljehamnen handles imports of gas
column19: oil and similar products. Since the 1950s
column20: the port of Södertälje has been important for the Swedish import of cars. About 80
column22: which corresponds to about 30 percent of total national car imports. Cars shipped to Södertälje are of Volkswagen

column1: Due to Södertälje's location close to a county border
column2: both SL and Sörmlandstrafiken operate buses in the city. The city bus network consists of around fifteen bus lines. They use the Central Railway Station as hub. Before Järnagatan street became pedestrian
column3: most buses would use that round trough the city centre. Most now take Nygatan street. In addition to regular city buses
column4: there are special services adapted to pensioners and people with disabilities known as Närtrafiken buses. Night services operate all night both weekends and weekdays. The city is served by two circular bus routes
column5: one on each side of the canal.

column1: Södertälje is particularly known for its two large companies Astra Zeneca and Scania. Measured in sheer number of companies
column2: the retail
column3: wholesale and restaurant sectors dominate
column4: with about 1
column5: 000 companies. The building and construction industry has about 600 companies in the Södertälje
column6: and some 450 companies in the consultancy sector. In total
column7: there are over 4
column8: 000 businesses in the city. Södertälje has a high number of small businesses with five or fewer employees.

column2: Apotekarnes Kemiska Fabriker was founded in 1913 by pharmacist Adolf Rising. Initially
column3: the company had only ten employees
column4: but already developed strongly during the first years. The company started with only five employees
column5: but grew exponentially in its first years of trading. One of the reasons was an increased need for medication due to the first world war. The company merged with its British competitor Zeneca in 1999
column6: and formed the pharmaceutical group Astra Zeneca. The company’s pill factory in Gärtuna in south-eastern Södertälje is the largest of its kind in the world
column7: employing over 3
column8: 200 people.

column2: Vagnfabriks-Aktiebolaget i Södertelge (abbreviated VABIS) started as manufacturier of railway cars
column3: petrol engines
column4: automobiles
column5: trucks
column6: motor-powered draisines
column7: motorboats and marine engines. In 1911 they merged with Maskinfabriks-aktiebolaget Scania and formed Scania-Vabis. The company only uses the name Scania AB today. The head office remains in its original location
column8: by Saltskogsfjärden south of the city centre of Södertälje. Together with its subsidiaries
column11: making the Group the largest employer.

column1: Most retail shopping is available in the city centre; predominantly on Storgatan and Järnagatan streets
column2: but also adjacent areas. The Kringlan department store was one of the first modern department stores when it opened in 1965.

column1: The name Kringlan (English: The Pretzel) is a reference to the long lasting local tradition of selling pretzels in Södertälje. Other department stores include Luna and Telgehuset. Retail shopping outside the city centre is mainly located in Moraberg on the eastern side of the canal
column2: as well as Vasa Handelsplats in the western part. Larger stores are also located around Hansaplan in the Södra area.

column1: KTH Royal Institute of Technology has a campus in Södertälje
column2: where they conduct university education within Mechanical engineering
column3: Logistics and other subjects all the way up to Master’s level including Master of Science in Engineering. Education is given in cooperation with the city’s two large corporations Scania AB and AstraZeneca. In 2018
column4: KTH moved in to a newly built campus in Södertälje Science Park drawn by the architect firm White. The Royal Institute of Technology has 1 200 students and hired researchers in Södertälje.Several universities conduct higher education at the learning centre Campus Telge. When it started it was located in Mariekälla
column5: but moved to new premises that previously housed the headquarters of Astra AB in 2015. Both individual courses and whole university programmes are offered within a variety of subjects
column6: meaning students can study at the campus all the way until graduation. Education within Yrkeshögskolan (English: Higher Vocational Education) is also held.Hagabergs folkhögskola started as a Bible Institute in 1910
column7: and became a folk high school in 1957. It is run by the Swedish Evangelical Mission. Around 250 students study at the academy
column8: of which 20 reside at the boarding school. The curriculum mostly centres on studies of Christian theology. The general introductory course for students pursuing a career within the Church of Sweden
column9: as well as “Allmän kurs” which is mostly non-religious and supplements normal secondary school education.In 2017
column11: 5 of which were municipal and 8 operated as charter schools.

column1: Södertälje's primary theatre is Oktoberteatern at Marenplan
column2: which has a number of new productions each year. The venue opened in 1928. It originally contained a cinema called Castor
column3: but was turned in to a theatre after a renovation in 1984. Södertälje is also home to Sweden's only professional Finnish-language theatre group; Teatteri Kipinä.One of the most popular cultural centre around the city is Kulturhuset i Ytterjärna (English: The Cultural Centre in Ytterjärna). The complex houses a theatre
column4: café
column5: conference rooms and offices. It opened in 1992
column6: and won second prize for Sweden's most popular modern building in 2001. During construction
column7: special attention was paid to the acoustics of the premises
column8: which has resulted in many concerts being held here. The concert hall has about 500 seats
column9: and together with other anthroposophical activities receives about 30
column10: 000 visitors annually. Other cultural activities include exhibitions on architecture and garden art.The stages Estrad and Trombon at the City Hall often show theatre as well as concerts and film. The association Molto has organised concerts and creative activities for youth since 2008. A recurring tradition in Södertälje is the local revue Täljerevyn
column11: which makes humorous cabarets about the city
column12: local traits and politics every year.

column1: Torekällbergets museum (colloquially referred to as just Torekällberget or simply Berget ) with the city museum Södertälje Stadsmuseum
column2: is one of the most popular sights to visit in the city. The museum first opened in 1929 when the landmark windmill and a few other buildings were moved to the site. In connection with the redevelopment of the city centre in 1961
column3: many old buildings were moved to Torekällberget. The museum is divided into the environments "Staden" (English: the City) and "Landet" (English: the Countryside). The urban environment is built around the main square Tenngjutartorget
column4: where markets often are held. The square is surrounded by buildings from the 1700-1800s. Several species of domestic animals are kept at the museum. The environment conveys a picture of life in rural farms around Södertälje in the 1800s and earlier. There is also a stage where ballroom dancing and performances are often arranged during the summer months.The vehicle museum Marcus Wallenberg-hallen (English: The Marcus Wallenberg Hall) is situated by Saltskogsfjärden
column5: next to the headquarters of Scania AB. The museum is named after the industrialist Marcus Wallenberg Jr.. The collections include a number of older vehicles and environments; like the first mass produced car in Sweden from 1903. It also features railway cars that were owned by the Swedish State Railways
column6: used between the late 1800s until the early 1900s. Exhibited objects have been restored to their original condition. A little less than half of the museum consists of newer vehicles manufactured during the 2000s.

column1: Södertälje is home to a large science museum based on the book La Science Amusante by French writer Arthur Good. The museum is called Tom Tits Experiment after the author’s pen name Tom Tit. It started as a temporary exhibition at Södertälje Hall of Arts (Swedish: Södertälje Konsthall)
column2: but became so popular that it was turned in to a permanent museum. The museum is located in an old industrial building at Storgatan street. Today
column3: it is the largest Science centre in Sweden. It occupies four floors
column4: and has a park that is open during the summer season. The exhibitions contain more than 400 science experiments. Tom Tits Experiment received around 190 000 visitors 2018.Saltskog gård (English: Saltskog manor) was the home of the industrialist and mecenate Carl Fredrik Liljevalch. Today it serves as a museum. The farm dates back to the 16th century. Liljevalch acquired it in 1881. Previously
column5: the farm had been owned by the families Lovisin
column6: Gyllenstierna
column7: Dufva and Tamm. Liljevalch did however became the first to actually settle there permanently. He took an active part in the daily activities on the farm
column8: and aspired that Saltskog gård would serve as a textbook example of ideal farming. He undertook extensive renovations of the farm and the estates to make them a cultural centre filled with art. An extension was made to the main building; and a smaller villa was added
column10: stables and outhouses. The garden contains several unusual species of trees and is designed as an English landscape garden. Two new commemorative rune stones were carved. Today
column11: the manor is run by a non-profit association. They have restored much of the premises in their original condition. There are several artist studios and exhibition halls. Concerts
column12: lectures and exhibitions are held all year round. During the summer season
column13: theatre is also performed in the gardens.

column1: Biologiska Museeet (English: The Museum of Biology) was donated to the city by patron Carl Fredrik Liljevalch. The building is in Art Nouveau style
column2: and located on Erik Dahlbergs road. It opened to the public in 1913
column3: thus making it the oldest museum in the city. The exhibitions were created by Gustaf Kolthoff and his son Kjell Kolthoff
column4: and show animals and birds from the province of Sörmland (where Södertälje is located) in their natural environments. In total
column5: there are over 100 different species on display. Kjell Kolthoff painted the large dioramas that have remained to this day. The museum was completely renovated and reopened in 1983.The world's oldest propeller-driven steamship which still has its original engine is S/S Ejdern. It was originally built by Götaverken in Gothenburg in 1880. During its first years
column6: Ejdern operated in the Gothenburg archipelago
column7: Lake Roxen
column8: and several ports in central Sweden. Since 1906
column9: it has had its home port in Södertälje.  The first route from the port in Södertälje was to Mörkö
column10: and cargo hauls in eastern Lake Mälaren . Between 1914 and 1957
column11: the boat had one single owner; Rickard Fredmark. He sold the boat to the City of Södertälje. At that time
column12: the ship was unprofitable and in very poor condition. The city subsequently decided that the boat was to be scrapped. In 1964 the boat was donated to an association for the preservation of old boats. Enthusiasts of this particular vessel broke out and formed Museiföreningen Ångfartyget Ejdern (English: The Museum Association S/S Ejdern)
column13: who still own the boat today. Since 1976 they operate museum routs around Södertälje. From 1984
column14: the boat is once again coal powered. S/S Ejdern has a capacity of 90 people
column15: and often operates the route to Adelsö and Viking city Birka.

column1: Wendela Hebbes hus (English: Wendela Hebbe’s house) is a museum of Wendela Hebbe
column2: who was the first female professional journalist in Sweden. She became employed at the newspaper Aftonbladet in 1841
column3: where she wrote about theatre and music
column4: and translated books. Besides being a journalist
column5: she also wrote fairy tales. The building is a yellow wooden house
column6: with two floors. It first stood at Snäckviken
column7: close to the headquarters of Astra AB. The property was purchased by Lars Johan Hierta in 1863 to serve as a summer house for Wendela
column8: her daughter Signe and the jointly unrecognised son Edvard Faustman. After being acquired by Södertälje Municipality it was moved to its present location between the canal and Marenplan in the city centre
column9: and underwent extensive renovations. The venue houses a restaurant and a museum section with furniture and paintings from the Hebbe and Faustman families. It also acts as a cultural centre
column10: hosting theatres and exhibitions.Södertälje Konsthall (English: Södertälje Museum of Arts) showcases various exhibitions of paintings
column11: sculptures and other artistic installations. The museum opened in 1968
column12: and relocated to its current premises in Luna in 1978. In 2015
column13: Grafikens Hus (English: House of Graphics) decided to relocate to the city from nearby Mariefred
column14: meaning there would be two art museums in Södertälje.

column1: Södertälje’s city library was originally run by an independent association
column2: but was taken over by the City council in 1945. It moved to its present location in 1978. Lectures
column3: courses and theatre are also held at the premises. The library has branches in Hölö
column4: Järna
column5: Enhörna
column6: Hovsjö and Mölnbo . The libraries in Enhörna
column7: Hölö and Mölnbo are combined school and public libraries.

column2: Södertälje BBK
column3: SBBK is one of the best in the country
column4: and Södertalje KINGS became Swedish Champions in 2013
column5: 2014 and 2015. In total SBBK has got 10 Gold for the male team Södertalje KINGS and 12 Gold for the female team Telge Basket. SBBK has in total 132 Swedish Championships since the star in 1968. Täljehallen is the home for SBBK.

column1: The city is home to Södertälje SK
column2: a classic and successful ice hockey team currently playing in Sweden's second highest league – HockeyAllsvenskan with Scaniarinken as their home arena. Assyriska FF and Syrianska FC are also two successful football clubs started in 1974 and 1977. They play at the same arena; Södertälje Fotbollsarena.

column1: Södertälje Storm Rugby League club are a pioneering Rugby league team
column2: playing in the Swedish National Rugby League
column3: which was formed in 2015.

column1: There is an indoor swimming arena in which elite training and races are held
column2: named Sydpoolen (English: the South pool).
and the rest of Stockholm region has a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfb) and displays four distinct seasons. Due to the city's high northerly latitude
column3: daylight varies widely from more than 18 hours around midsummer
column4: to only around 6 hours in midwinter. Södertälje has much warmer and sunnier weather than other locations at the same latitude mainly because of the influence of Gulf Stream. The city enjoys 1
column5: 981 hours of sunshine annually.

column1: Summers have an average daytime high temperatures of 20–23 °C (68–73 °F) and lows of around 15 °C (59 °F)
column2: but there are periods of heat waves and many days with temperatures above 25 °C (77 °F)+). Winters are cold
column3: though sometimes milder with temperatures ranging from −3 to 1 °C (27 to 34 °F)
column4: while spring and autumn mainly cool.

column1: Annual precipitation is 539 mm (21.2 in) with light to moderate rainfall throughout the year. Snow mainly occurs from December through March
column2: but snow covers does not remain for a long time.
